reg:regulation.reg:title: Pool Regulation

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Public Health Act;
commercial pool means an artificially created body of water that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has a depth of at least 61 cm,
is owned or operated by, or in conjunction with,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a business enterprise that maintains private rooms, or camping sites, for the accommodation of the public, other than a business enterprise that maintains fewer than 4 units or sites,
a business enterprise that offers services that are available only to persons holding membership with the enterprise, or
a strata corporation as defined in the Strata Property Act, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is to be used only by members, shareholders, tenants or patrons of the enterprise or strata corporation, or their guests;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: construction includes the design, installation, repair, renovation and alteration of a pool;
hot tub means an artificially created body of water that is used as a hydrotherapy pool or swirl pool, or for similar recreational bathing or therapeutic purposes;
pool means a commercial pool, hot tub, public pool, spray pool or wading pool, and includes any

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: facilities,
auxiliary structures,
equipment,
play equipment, and
moving water features such as wave or whirlpool actions

bcl:definition.bcl:text: that are associated with the use or operation of a pool;
pool patron means a person within the pool enclosure, whether or not the person is using the pool or has paid a fee to be within the pool enclosure;
public pool means an artificially created body of water that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has a depth of at least 61 cm,
is available to the public for swimming, recreational bathing or physiotherapy purposes, either free of charge or for a fee, and
is not a commercial pool;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: spray pool means an artificially created depression or basin into which water is sprayed but not permitted to accumulate;
wading pool means an artificially created body of water intended for wading purposes and having a depth of less than 61 cm.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This regulation applies to all pools except the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a private residential pool that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: has been installed, whether permanently or temporarily, for the use of the occupants and guests of one single family dwelling or duplex, whether the dwelling or duplex is owned or leased or occupied with permission of the owner or lessor, and
is not a common facility owned by a strata corporation or other corporate body;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a pool located within an individual room of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a hotel, or
another place in which private rooms are maintained for the accommodation of the public;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a pool that is drained and cleaned following each use;

a pool that would be a commercial pool, except that it is owned or operated by, or in conjunction with, a business enterprise that maintains fewer than 4 units or camping sites for the accommodation of the public.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sections 7 (1), 8 (2) (a) (ii), 9 (b), 10 (2) (a) and (j), 14 and 17 do not apply to spray pools,
section 10 (2) (d) to (i) does not apply to spray pools that use a continuous supply of water of a quality satisfactory to a health officer, and
this regulation does not apply, in the manner set out in Schedule 1, to a pool contained in a swimming facility described in Schedule 1.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of the Act,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: risks to sanitation, water quality and public safety in relation to a pool are prescribed as health hazards, and
the construction and operation of a pool are prescribed as regulated activities.

bcl:definition.bcl:text: architect means a person who is registered or licensed under the Professional Governance Act;
engineer means a person who is registered under the Professional Governance Act as a professional engineer or professional licensee engineering.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (6), a person must not construct a pool unless the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: holds a construction permit issued under this regulation, and
complies with the terms and conditions, if any, of the permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may apply for a construction permit by submitting to a health officer an application accompanied by the plans and specifications for the construction as prepared, sealed and certified by an engineer or architect.

A health officer may issue a construction permit in respect of a pool if satisfied that the pool, if constructed according to the plans and specifications submitted with the application, will not likely constitute a health hazard.
If an application indicates that a pool will be constructed in phases, and the plans and specifications submitted with the application relate only to one or more phases,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the health officer may issue a construction permit that authorizes construction only of that phase or those phases,
a new application must be submitted for each subsequent phase or set of phases, and
subsection (3) applies to each new application, considered in the context of the previous phases.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without prior written approval from a health officer, a person must not construct a pool other than in accordance with the plans and specifications submitted with the application.
Despite subsection (1), a health officer may waive the requirement for a construction permit

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on request of a person and after receiving any information the health officer may require, and
if the proposed construction is a repair or alteration

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: performed for emergency purposes, or
that is so minor that requiring a construction permit is not necessary to protect the public interest.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person must not operate a pool unless the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: holds an operating permit issued under this regulation, and
complies with the terms and conditions, if any, of the permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may apply for an operating permit by submitting to a health officer an application accompanied by the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if no operating permit has ever been issued for the pool, or the pool has undergone construction since an operating permit was last issued,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a signed statement from an engineer or architect that the pool has been constructed so as to substantially comply, in all material respects, with the plans and specifications submitted under section 5 (2) [construction permit required], and
a copy of the pool safety plan prepared in accordance with section 13;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the fee required under Schedule 2.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A health officer may issue an operating permit in respect of a pool if satisfied that the operation of the pool will not likely constitute a health hazard.
An operating permit

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is not transferable,
must be posted in a prominent place on the premises, and
expires on the earlier of the date specified in the permit, if any, and one year following the permit's issue.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), an operating permit is not required to operate a spray pool that meets all of the following requirements:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the water source is a water supply system within the meaning of the Drinking Water Protection Act;
the water drains to a system that collects waste water;
drained water is not recirculated;

if the spray pool is subject to a construction permit issued under section 5, the operator submits to a health officer a signed statement from an engineer or architect that the pool has been constructed so as to substantially comply, in all material respects, with the plans and specifications submitted under section 5 (2) in respect of the application for the construction permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must erect and maintain around the pool and its walkways a fence or other barrier with controlled access to prevent access by animals and persons who are not pool patrons.
Subsection (1) does not apply to the operator of a wading pool that is drained before dark and left empty overnight.
An operator must post in a prominent position within the pool enclosure a sign stating the rules of the pool.
The rules posted under subsection (1) must prohibit the following behaviours:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: entering the pool

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: with an illness, including open sores, bandages, head colds, discharging ears or noses or infected eyes, or
without having first taken a cleansing shower;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: running, fighting or engaging in other conduct likely to cause an injury while in the pool enclosure;
contaminating or fouling the pool;
failing to immediately report to the operator or lifeguard an injury suffered while in the pool enclosure, or contamination or fouling of the pool;
failing to supervise children for whom one is responsible while in the pool enclosure;
diving into the pool, except in designated areas.
the pool is kept clean and clear of obstructions,
soap in dispensers, and either air dryers or single-use hand towels, are supplied near the hand basins, and
if supplied by the operator, bathing suits and bath towels are laundered after each use and stored and handled in a sanitary manner.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, design flow rate means the rate at which water must be recirculated or replaced in order to turn over the entire volume of pool water within a period of time specified in the plans submitted under section 5 [construction permit required].
An operator must meet the following requirements in respect of water in the pool:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pool water must be clear enough that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the pattern of the main drain, or
a black disc of 150 mm in diameter over a white background,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: located at the deepest point of the pool, can be seen clearly by a person standing on the edge of the pool overlooking the main drain or disc;
pool water, except in a hot tub, must be maintained at a temperature of no more than 37C;
the microbiological quality of pool water must not present a risk to the health of pool patrons;
the pH level of pool water must be tested at least twice daily and maintained at no less than 7.2 and no more than 7.8;
the alkalinity of pool water must be tested at least weekly and maintained at a level no less than 80 parts per million and no more than 120 parts per million;
disinfectants used in pool water must be tested at least twice daily and maintained in accordance with Schedule 3;
the combined chlorine in pool water must be tested at least twice daily and maintained at a concentration of less than one part per million;
if cyanuric acid stabilizer is used in pool water, it must be tested at least weekly and maintained at a concentration of less than 80 parts per million;
pool water must be recirculated or replaced at the design flow rate;
pool water must be circulated through the skimmers or overflow gutters at a rate of flow at least equal to 50% of the design flow rate while the pool is in use;
subject to subsection (3), pool water must not pass through any drain grate at a speed greater than 46 cm per second when the pool is operating at the design flow rate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A health officer may waive, in writing, the requirement set out in subsection (2) (k) in relation to a specified pool if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the pool is used for exercise, commonly known as a "swim in place" pool, and
the health officer is satisfied that the design of the pool will not create a suction hazard.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A health officer may impose a different requirement than set out in subsection (2) (d), (e), (f) or (g) in relation to a specified pool if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a more stringent requirement is, in the opinion of the health officer, necessary to prevent a health hazard, or
the health officer is satisfied that the different requirement is sufficient to prevent a health hazard.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to any other power that may be exercised under the Act, a health officer may require an operator to test for chemical, physical or biological characteristics of water in a pool.
An operator must ensure that the pool is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: maintained on a regular basis by a person who, in the opinion of a health officer, has appropriate training, and
kept in good repair so that no health hazard exists, including ensuring that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: water intakes do not present a suction hazard to pool patrons, and
nothing in the pool presents an entrapment hazard to pool patrons.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the pool enclosure is sufficiently lit so that all areas are visible to pool patrons, lifeguards and operators,
pool equipment is regularly tested for safety and maintained in accordance with the manufacturers' specifications,
pool aprons, walkways and floors have a surface that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is slip-resistant when wet, and
slopes away from the pool such that, when the aprons, walkways and floors are wet, water does not accumulate or flow back into the pool

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the nose of any step or ledge in the pool is marked in a contrasting colour to the remainder of the step or ledge,
handrails at steps, ladders and diving boards are secure,
the numerical depth of water in the pool is clearly marked,
hot water provided in pool facilities is no more than 49C, and
chemicals are stored in a safe manner and location.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An operator must not permit an animal to enter the pool enclosure, other than a guide dog or a service dog, as defined in the Guide Dog and Service Dog Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepare a written pool safety plan in accordance with subsection (2) to ensure the health and safety of pool patrons,
make the plan readily available to pool employees,
train each pool employee in the procedures and in the use of the equipment described in the plan,
review and update the pool safety plan at least once each year, and
ensure that each pool employee complies with the pool safety plan.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The pool safety plan must include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: procedures to be followed in the event of a serious injury, emergency or incident,
the type of lifesaving, lifeguarding and first aid equipment to be kept within the immediate vicinity of the pool,
the number of lifeguards and other employees who are to be on duty while the pool is in use in order to ensure adequate supervision of pool patrons,
operating procedures for the pool, and
the program of cleaning and maintenance of the pool, including the nature and frequency of the cleaning and maintenance.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An operator of a public pool must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a telephone for use in an emergency is accessible without charge to pool patrons,
the location of the telephone is marked conspicuously with a sign, and
telephone numbers of the nearest hospital, ambulance service, police department and fire department are displayed near the telephone.

bcl:section.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that drinking water is reasonably accessible by pool patrons.
The operator of a hot tub must ensure that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the hot tub enclosure has, in easy view of all users of the hot tub,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a clock prominently displaying the time, and
instructions for the safe use of the hot tub, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the water in the hot tub is maintained at a temperature of no more than 40C.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is at least 16 years of age,
is trained in the procedures and in the use of the equipment described in the pool safety plan,
is responsible for the conduct and safety of all pool patrons, and
is performing no duty other than pool surveillance;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: pool safety plan means the pool safety plan prepared in accordance with section 13.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A public pool operator must ensure that, when the pool is open to the public,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pool supervision is provided by at least one lifeguard and any additional lifeguards as required by the pool safety plan, and
at least one additional person is on duty within the swimming facility and available to assist the lifeguard in an emergency, and that person is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: trained in the procedures and in the use of the equipment described in the pool safety plan, and
designated by the operator for the purpose of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A public pool operator may operate the pool without lifeguards during any period of time that all of the following circumstances apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the only persons permitted access to the pool are persons receiving aquatic instruction who are closely supervised by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an aquatic instructor, and
at least one additional person responsible for assisting the instructor,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: both of whom are trained in the emergency procedures and in the use of the emergency equipment described in the pool safety plan;
a clearly visible sign is posted at each entrance to the pool stating that no lifeguard is on duty and that children must be supervised by an adult;
the pool is equipped with a reaching assist and a throwing ring, as described in section 18 (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The operator of a commercial pool, hot tub, spray pool or wading pool must ensure that, when the pool is open to bathers and no lifeguard is on duty, a clearly visible notice is posted at each entrance to the pool stating that no lifeguard is on duty and that children must be supervised by an adult.

In addition to the requirement under subsection (1), the operator of a commercial pool, or a hot tub with an area of more than 10 m2, must ensure that, when the pool is open to bathers, it is equipped with

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a non-conducting reaching assist of at least 3.5 m in length, with a shepherd's hook, and
a throwing ring, securely attached to a line of at least 6 mm diameter and having a length of at least half the width of the pool plus 3 m.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An operator must ensure that, for each pool operated by the operator, a daily record is kept of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all injuries sustained at or within the pool;
all occurrences of contamination by feces or vomit at or within the pool;
the amount and types of chemicals added to the pool water;
the results of all tests performed as required under section 10 (2) and (4) [pool water].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The operator must ensure that the records required under subsection (1) are available for inspection by a health officer on request.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The following are exempt from the regulation:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the swimming facility in Dawson Creek known as "Rotary Lake";
the swimming facility in Ladysmith known as "4 All Seasons Resort Pool";
the swimming facility near Ladysmith known as "Yellow Point Lodge Salt Water Pool";
the swimming facility near Pemberton known as "Meager Creek Hotsprings Pools";
the swimming facility in Whistler known as "H2Air Water Ramp".

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exemptions from circulation rate and public pool supervision requirements
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following are exempt from sections 10 (2) (j) and 17 of the regulation:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the swimming facility in Ainsworth known as "Ainsworth Hotspring Pool";
the swimming facility in Nakusp known as "Nakusp Hotspring Pool";
the 3 upper level pools at the swimming facility near Nakusp known as "Halcyon Hot Springs".

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who submits, under section 6 of the regulation, an application for an operating permit must include with the application a fee of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: $150, if the area of the pool is less than 19 m2, or
$250, if the area of the pool is 19 m2 or more.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite section 1 of this Schedule, if a person intends to operate more than one pool, each of which is located either in or adjacent to a single building or on a site that has a hotel, the person must include with the applications

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the fee as determined under section 1 of this Schedule for the largest pool, and
a fee of $75 for each of the remaining pools.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite section 1, if a person is applying for an operating permit that is to be issued for only part of a fiscal year, the person must include with the application a fee calculated using the following formula:

oasis:entry.oasis:line: months is the number of calendar months of the fiscal year in which the permit will apply, and
fee is the applicable fee under section 1 of this Schedule.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, ppm means parts per million.
For the purposes of section 10 [pool water] of the regulation, an operator must use a disinfectant listed in Column 1 of the table, maintained at least in the concentration set out in

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Column 2, if the temperature of the water in the pool is less than or equal to 30C, and
Column 3, if the temperature of the water in the pool is greater than 30C.
